parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post information.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. While the post promotes voting, it does not explicitly mention any specific parliamentary candidate by name or party affiliation from the provided list. The post is in Hungarian, and refers to the general importance of voting, not a specific candidate.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, and its message ("Vote on Sunday!") is clearly intended for a wide audience, not a specific individual.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>True. The primary objective of the post is to encourage people to vote. While it doesn't endorse a specific candidate, urging people to vote inherently influences the electoral outcome by increasing voter turnout.  The text expresses a sense of urgency and implies negative consequences for not voting.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>False. The post lacks the characteristics of journalistic reporting. It doesn't present factual information, analysis, or diverse perspectives. Instead, it presents a strongly opinionated call to action, urging voters to participate in the election.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>False. While the post expresses a personal opinion about the importance of voting, it goes beyond simply expressing an opinion and actively encourages a specific action (voting) with an implied political motivation. The urgency and the framing of the situation as a threat to the Hungarian minority in Romania strongly suggests an electoral objective.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>2032887200488828</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post, while not explicitly endorsing a specific candidate, constitutes electoral propaganda. It directly encourages voting, which influences the electoral outcome. The post's message, "Vote on Sunday!", coupled with the accompanying text expressing concerns about the potential success of "anti-Hungarian forces," creates a strong call to action with a clear political undertone.  The paid nature of the post on a public platform further strengthens the argument for it being electoral propaganda.  The fact that it is targeted at a specific demographic (Hungarian speakers in Romania) further suggests an attempt to influence the election.  While it doesn't violate Article 36 (7) - a (direct reference to a candidate), it clearly fulfills criteria b (used during the electoral campaign), c (electoral objective), and arguably d (goes beyond journalistic information).
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>TRUE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates>
</electoral-propaganda-candidates>
<responsible-party-or-group>RMDSZ</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police>
RMDSZ, pentru încălcarea articolului 98 t) din LEGEA nr. 208 din 20 iulie 2015, prin publicarea unei reclame plătite pe Facebook cu mesajul „VASĂRNAP SZAVAZOK!”, urmat de un text care exprimă îngrijorare față de potențialul succes al unor „forțe anti-maghiare”, având ca efect electoral mobilizarea alegătorilor maghiari din România, în ciuda faptului că perioada de campanie electorală s-a încheiat după ora 18:00 pe 23.11.2024.  Postarea, având un caracter persuasiv și îndemnând la vot fără a specifica un candidat anume, constituie propagandă electorală, influențând rezultatul alegerilor prin creșterea prezenței la vot în rândul unui anumit segment al populației. ID-ul postării pe Facebook este 2032887200488828.
</message-for-police>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
